Award.AwardTitle: Dominant Categories, Industry Life Cycles and Entry Timing Advantages

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study blends established theories of industry life cycles and first-mover advantages with recent sociological research on categorization to yield a novel way of understanding some of the key dynamics of early industries. The research team will explore how the creation of categories and labels affect the emergence of a new industry and the performance of its players. The researchers anticipate that the emergence of a "dominant category" in the market space can have profound implications on the entry timing and positioning strategies of participating firms. They will look at the performance implications of firms' choices of categories and positioning for their products: e.g., type and number of categories used; consistency in their use across products; consistency between categorization and products? technical features.

The research program combines the development of new theoretical models with a careful empirical research design. Using primary and secondary data from the "smartphone" market space, this interdisciplinary research team will test a number of hypotheses about the relationship between category formation, timing of entry, and firm performance. Having emerged in the last decade or so, smartphones represent a large and fast-growing market space with high variance in the number and kinds of labels used to describe product and feature offerings. This study will develop a fine-grained analysis of industry evolution that should eventually help firms make more nuanced strategic decisions regarding when and how to enter a particular industry. It should also have implications for policy makers seeking to understand how to meaningfully influence the development paths of new industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We set out to provide fresh theorizing and empirical evidence regarding the difficult question of how people’s understandings of technologies shape the evolution of industries and impact firm performance. Our previous combined training in strategy, the management of technology and innovation, and sociology of organizations made this ambitious pursuit possible and all the more interesting for the co-principal investigators. We decided to tackle some big questions in these bodies of literature by trying to integrate ideas about how technologies evolve during industry emergence with theories of how people make sense of these same technologies. Our publication strategy was to focus on the most prestigious academic journals in order to maximize peer visibility, but at the same target highly respected publications in management oriented primarily to practitioners, in order to maximize the scope of our impact. While we were successful in pursuing both types of outlets, as we close our project our pipeline is still strong with two more scholarly papers and one practitioner-oriented paper either in review or in the making. We provide below a brief summary of some of the key findings from our project.

We first tackled a central question in strategy: What is the optimal time for a firm to enter an emerging industry? Scholars have for decades struggled to create a theoretical foundation that could integrate conflicting empirical findings on this matter. Our contribution here, already a published paper in Strategic Management Journal, consisted of incorporating insights from categorical dynamics to industry lifecycle theory in order to enhance existing theories of entry timing. In particular, this paper introduces the concept of a dominant category—the conceptual schema that most stakeholders adhere to when referring to products that address similar needs and compete for the same market space. We link the idea of a dominant category with the well-known concept of a dominant technological design to come up with fresh theorizing about the optimal time of entry. We propose the existence of a window of opportunity for firm entry that starts with the emergence of the dominant category and ends with the emergence of the dominant design. The attached Figure 1 illustrates our key points.

Encouraged by our first article, we decided to address the more fundamental question of how technological designs and categories co-evolve. We built upon these two literatures to propose an integrative model of how industries emerge and evolve. This work, now a published paper in Academy of Management Review, proposes that the evolution of both technological designs and categories follows a similar pattern, characterized by an early period of divergence followed by a period of convergence. We identify the mechanisms that account for this co-evolutionary process; that is, the mechanisms through which designs evolve and how different stakeholders’ categorical understandings shape design competition. Likewise, we propose that category evolution is a contested process of category creation and selection, which in turn is influenced by the designs that the categories are trying to group. Our model creates a much-needed bridge between two bodies of literature that, while addressing similar topics, have evolved largely separately.

We used these insights to come up with some practical implications, in a paper we published in the MIT Sloan Management Review. Here we alert managers of the importance of having a “labeling strategy” when they enter a new industry.
